title: How to Reduce Energy Use in the Kitchen

steps.headline: Realize energy savings of about 20 percent by using a convection oven, which  circulates air around the food you are cooking.
steps.description: Convection ovens work better the more surface area the food has. That is, they will work better on cookies or muffins than banana bread. You may need to reduce the baking time a little when using convection.

steps.headline: Use a microwave oven when possible.
steps.description: Although microwave ovens use more energy than conventional ovens, the shorter cooking time saves energy.

steps.headline: Bake in glass or ceramic vessels.
steps.description: They let you reduce the oven temperature as much as 25 degrees (13.88 degrees C).

steps.headline: Keep the oven door closed.
steps.description: Don't open the door to peek at the food, as opening the door reduces the temperature by up to 50 degrees (27 degrees C).

steps.headline: Bake more than one thing at a time.
steps.description: For example, if you're roasting a chicken, you could also roast potatoes and vegetables alongside it. You might even be able to bake bread, biscuits, or dessert.

steps.headline: Turn off the oven a few minutes early, and let the food continue to cook in the heat still in the oven.
Cover pans whenever possible, as leaving pans uncovered while cooking results in more heat loss.
Turn off the stove burner a few minutes early when boiling foods such as pasta, potatoes and eggs, as the hot water continues to cook the food.
Use the correct burner for the job.
steps.description: If you use a large burner for a small pan, you waste electricity or gas. Turn the flame or coil down to the minimum setting for the heat you need to cook your food adequately. For example, smaller pots of water boil when the burner is set lower.

steps.headline: Use the minimum amount of water when boiling food.
steps.description: The more water you use, the more energy is required to bring the water to a boil and keep it boiling.

steps.headline: Use a pressure cooker to save energy and reduce cooking time.
steps.description: Pressure cookers, which are either stovetop or electric, raise the temperature of water before boiling and trap steam. Do a web search for pressure cooker recipes.

steps.headline: Cut food into smaller pieces to reduce cooking time.
Increase the amount of food you make so you can refrigerate or freeze the food and simply reheat it later.
steps.description: Preparing meals from the beginning uses more energy than reheating food. Save energy by reheating food on the stove or in the microwave oven rather than a conventional oven.

steps.headline: Thaw food in the refrigerator instead of using a microwave or conventional oven.
Grill outdoors.
steps.description: This uses less energy than a stove or oven. Grilling outdoors also prevents heat from being released into your house, which may cause increased air conditioner use.

steps.headline: Run the dishwasher only when it is full.
Wash dishes with the plug in the sink.
steps.description: Don't wash under running water, especially not hot water.

steps.headline: Blow, brush, or vacuum the dust off the refrigerator coils about once per year.
steps.description: Dust and debris insulate the heat exchange process, and reduce your refrigerator's efficiency.

steps.headline: Clean the inside of your microwave when it gets splattered with food.
steps.description: Use a cover to prevent splatters. Messy microwaves heat less efficiently.
